The confidence fairy has been a no-show in austerityville, but then the deficit fairy hasn't exactly been working magic in those countries where she's been unleashed. I prefer Keynesians to the fresh water folk, but only those economists who've noticed the radical imbalances and structural distortions of the WTO version of globalization can possibly devise workable solutions. The housing bubbles in the US, Ireland, Spain and elsewhere and the bloated financial sector that crashed the world were all pumped up by cheap money--the glut of recycled dollars from surplus nations such as China, Saudi Arabia and others.

We deem China a legitimate member of the global economic community and even offer incentives to our manufacturing and retail corporations to produce or source there, which they have done with great zest. Meanwhile Beijing has made a mockery of the democratic virtues, labor rights, environmental regulations, and other pillars of civil society and the good life now under threat in the US and Europe.

Of course we need stimulus dollars to stave off the collapse of our struggling public scools sytems and to employ the idle human capital embodied in unemployed, highly trained teachers and civil servants. And we should prudently test the limits of deficit spending to fund that stop gap measure. But more than that we must begin rethinking the architecture of the global and domestic economies so that they once again serve human needs and environmental sustainability.

The policy of austerity is not due to "wrong-headed" thinking. The biggest banks have speculated on European government debt and driven up interest rates. They want to keep that money coming. That means cut social spending, jobs, wages, pensions. And what is being done in the public sector is also being done in the private sector. And for the same reason. Downsizing, wage cuts, pension cuts all produce higher profits. And the question of how corporate profits drives policy is exactly what Krugman won't go near.

Social security, Medicare, and Medicaid are A problem but not THE problem. All of those programs are decades away from insolvency. The urgent issue is depressed consumer demand which is holding the economy well below capacity. Focusing on our long term entitlement problems rather than demand is like focusing on your high cholesterol while you have a wound that is gushing blood. The analogy is also appropriate in that premature austerity actually hurts our ability to deal with the long term fiscal problems because it delays the return to normal economic conditions and the increased tax revenues that come along with that.

The budget cutters have unfortunately been boxed in too discretionary spending, which is too small of a pool to make a difference. Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid are the 3 elephants in the corner of the room - unless those programs are back on the table, it won't matter - the budget will stay out of whack.

That is the problem in southern Europe, and that will be the problem here.

It's energy, energy and energy! If not for oil and coal corporations we would have already couple of millions more jobs in the energy sector. The US gas extraction is increasing and nuclear power plants will be constructed under Obama, which is good, if only done safely of course! But that is not enough. We need more investment in other energy sources, and these investments do not need to be paid in borrowed money. With most big corporations paying Zero in taxes, and milioneres paying 15% tax, we have easily 200-300 billions in "reserves" to finance energy investments.

I guess I would gently suggest that, without judging or abandoning those who've already made this call, it might be better for both society and individuals if the "choice" wasn't one between an unhappy marriage and single parenthood, but between having a child young and unmarried, and waiting until a more stable moment--married, or not--to do so. The time to determine if a partner is a drain on resources and master at creating chaos is, if at all possible (and of course accidents happen, and no birth control method is foolproof) before deciding to have children.

This isn't an article, or a statistic, based on men and women setting out to build a committed life together, having children, and then having that commitment fail. The numbers suggest that it's not about that small subset of women whose birth control fails them, either. It's based on a large number of people of both sexes choosing to have children outside of what remains, in the country, the most significant signifier of that commitment. It's true that in many other countries, co-habitiating can be just as secure and lasting as marriage. It's simply not statistically true here--and certainly not for the people profiled in the original article.

What you said about enjoying editing crosswords far more than constructing them exactly parallels my feeling about writing versus editing. In my long career as an editor I had to do plenty  major rewriting but I almost never wrote anything from scratch. Being able to spot the problems in a manuscript and fix them (or guide the writer toward needed revisions) was challenging, fun, and rewarding, and the rewards were even greater when I got a note of appreciation from a writer.

Paulymath's experience parallels mine very closely. I have spent 40 years editing and rewriting for others and have always shined in the afterglow of their success. What fun to send a marked-up manuscript back to an author and get a "Wow" response. You really have me thinking!" On the puzzle front, I am a solver, not a constructor, but occasionally would be delighted to be asked to edit clues!

I'm a seven-day solver, just because I formed the habit decades ago. When I first came to NYC, I started the day with coffee and the paper (NYT), which included the puzzle. The habit stuck, even after the puzzles became all scheduled on a difficulty level.

Full disclosure: I spent some time in those early decades editing pulp XW/wordgame magazines, and wound up necessarily doing my fair share of constructing. Fuller disclosure: I wasn't a very good constructor, and never particularly enjoyed it. It was a lot more fun to rework other constructors' submissions and make them better. Say what you will.

My point is that I understand the challenge/gratification/frustration of the constructor, at least to a point. I don't mind that the early-week puzzles are easy, but I like them to have fun with words on whatever level. And I want that same sense of playfulness in the more challenging late-week puzzles. I'm happy enough with "easy" rather than "hard," or vice versa, but I'm disappointed when the constructor doesn't tease me a bit.

Gawd, that sounds pedantic! But that's my say.

BTW, back in those decades-ago Dark Ages, we didn't refer to "grids" but to "diagrams." Cf. "diagramless."

After the 2008 collapse America was like a nation where everyone ran for cover from a storm by seeking shelter in the same house. There was bickering in this house, and a few have had an interest in knocking it down (the GOP) in the hopes the ensuing chaos will benefit them. However, despite the bad weather and a few rabble rousers, the house remains standing thanks to a President that has proven his ability to lead by staying on course and above the fray.

Europe is experiencing that same storm. A bit less severe in terms of debt, but their problem is exacerbated by the fact that they all ran for cover in multiple directions to seek shelter in different houses. Each house is subjecting them to different parts of the storm where splintered groups can't agree on the same prescription for survival. The result: the calamity of disunion now threatens to be worse than the storm itself.

While the EU doesn't have to contend with a reckless Party hellbent on economic sabotage like in America, they do have their largest economic bloc satisfied to stay the course of austerity. That bloc of course is Germany. Led by Chancellor Merkel, an opportunist who gauges the political zeitgeist by sticking her finger in the wind to see which way it's blowing, Europe is guaranteed to have a faithful ally of austerity.

There maybe no greater insult than to equate Europe's largest economy with the GOP, but the similarities regarding the negative effects they're both having on growth is undeniable.

The pain caucus doesn't actually care whether austerity works or not; any excuse to cut government spending would be fine with them. And oddly enough, critical as they are of government, they have an unfaltering faith that the private sector will make all good if the government just gets out of the way and quits holding them back. You'd think the events of the recent past would have them a little more chary about that belief.

You could be excused for wondering if the pain caucus has a rather different agenda than the one they've announced publicly; when someone repeats actions that have inevitably gone badly in the past, perhaps there is something about those results that they actually desire.

Very wise answer. You understand that their is some "cultural level" involved. Mostly this is ignored, because it may imply "overgeneralizations".

But as a European, I know and understand very well that culture is different in the US. And I absolutely adore US culture for what it is: friendly, helpful, pragmatic and a doers mentality (the latter we absolutely lack in most of Europe). No one should ever have to make excuses for their own culture.

That said, I do notice some other aspects of American cultural that in my eyes are merely confusions: taking things to seriously (which is expressed very often with exaggerated ego-talk), a clinging to materialistic thinking (simplifying the world in to good and better, while overlooking the different and even cyclic scales that may apply), etc. Small things. But you do notice them. Somehow I also have the feeling that these aspects can cause quite some social pressure on people. I am convinced that this all translates into parenting somehow.

Somehow I also have the feeling that these aspects can cause quite some social pressure on people. Maybe American parents should let go of their tendencies to please their materialistic cohort and just be also pragmatic in parenting.

In my experience, as an American, American parents are very, very touchy about implied inferiority of their parenting styles, and tend to be resistant to implications that they could do things better. For example read some of the comments about the recent autism aritcle which pointed to ways in which parents might unwittingly disrupt their child's development. Everybody took it as a personal affront to parenthood rather than thinking about how this scientific data could inform their parenting choices.

Perhaps that touchiness is true about other cultures too, or perhaps it's why we're not great parents overall. I can only speak for myself, but I do not think we raise children well. We shower them with empty praise, mixed signals, and give them little preparation for handling life's difficulties or challenges. That's true on a cultural level, even if not for everybody. Every parenting style has different pluses and minuses, but I think the only thing the American style does uniquely is produce egocentric, materialistic brats.

Because business will only spend money when they see a chance of a better return, which in a down economy is rare.  The government can choose to spend money without expecting any return other than economic stimulus.  And when the economy booms, the government can pay down its deficit with higher tax revenues and reduced stimulus.

It is simple Dan. The idea is that government can spend now and then pay back over time once the crisis is over. Example: the government spends $20 billion now on roads, bridges, etc. to get the economy moving again and pays for it over 20 years ($1 billion per year).

So the short term effect is $20 billion to GDP plus the money multiplier as construction workers that would otherwise be unemployed purchase cars, toys, etc. AND are no longer on unemployment. This multiplier gets the private sector growing and hiring again so that when the stimulus subsides the economy can sustain growth on its own.

it's very simple, Dan. In the short term, there is inadequate private spending to propel us into the long term. The sooner real growth occurs, the sooner government revenue increases to pay down that indebtedness that so terrifies you. (See Clinton administration.) In a stagnant or shrinking economy, there is no way to catch up. (See Bush 43, 2nd term.)

Why should government spending grow an economy over the long term better than the money being spent in the private sector?  You again seem to advocate a free lunch whereby a dollar spent by the gov't has a multiplier effect larger than that of the dollar spent by the private sector.  Over some time period too short or too long one can show austerity works or stimulus works, or neither does. the difference is that austerity doesn't leave behind an indebted gov't, so why not use the cheaper option?Unless the readers are aware of both keynes and hayek it's deceptive to suggest there is but one approach and all the conservatives against yours, the keynesian one, are ignorant or deceptive.

One should give credit where credit is due, but the conclusion espoused here is utter nonsense:

"The announcement Saturday that Foxconn Technology — one of the world’s largest electronics manufacturers — will sharply raise salaries and reduce overtime at its Chinese factories signals that pressure from workers, international markets and concerns among Western consumers about working conditions is driving a fundamental shift that could accelerate an already rapidly changing Chinese economy."

How do I know it's nonsense? Foxconn posted a jobs notice 3 weeks ago with the exact same wage increases at their plant in Zhengzhou, before this recent round of supposed external "pressure". This is fundamental economics. There's an increasing labor shortage in China, and as a result wages are increasing in response. That's it. Occam's Razor. Nothing fancy. No patting oneself on the back necessary.

You can see the three week old job posting listing the higher salaries at Flickr, and also at the MIC Gadget website 3 weeks ago:

The answer is that there is nothing more dear to politicians than reelection, and it is the corporations who have the vast amount of money that they need. If to get that money means to stand by silently while workers and taxpayers take the hit, then that is what our politicians will do.

In my wife's country, this phenomenon would be called "graft and corruption."

Here in the US, we call it "lobbying."

The most amazing part of all this is that, with the exception of the Occupy movements, the American people have yet to take to the streets.

One wonders when there will be, like in Arabic countries, an American spring?
